To be in your children\'s memories tomorrow,You have to be in their lives today.\n\n ― Barbara Johnson
“It is easier to build stronger children than to repair broken men”\n\n ― Frederick Douglas
“Tell me and I forget, teach me and I may remember, involve me and I learn.”\n\n ― Benjamin Franklin
“What it\'s like to be a parent: It\'s one of the hardest things you\'ll ever do but in exchange it teaches you the meaning of unconditional love.”\n\n ― Nicholas Sparks, The Wedding
“There really are places in the heart you don\'t even know exist until you love a child.” \n\n ― Anonymous
“Character is what you have left when you\'ve lost everything you can lose”\n\n ― Evan Esar
“No occupation in this world is more trying to soul and body than the care of young children..”\n\n ― Isabella MacDonald Alden
“Your children need your presence more than your presents.”\n\n ― Jesse Jackson
“Parents can tell but never teach, unless they practice what they preach.”\n\n ― Arnold H. Glasow
“At the end of the day, the most overwhelming key to a child\'s success is the positive involvement of parents.”\n\n ― Jane D. Hull
“Always kiss your children goodnight, even if they\'re already asleep.”\n\n ― H. Jackson Brown, Jr.
“I regret not having had more time with my kids when they were growing up.”\n\n ― Tina Turner
"To be in your children\'s memories tomorrow, you have to be in their lives today."\n\n ― Unknown
“Everything depends on upbringing”.\n\n ― Leo Tolstoy
“We never know the love of the parent till we become parents ourselves”\n\n ― Henry Ward Beecher
“To bring up a child in the way he should go - travel that way yourself”\n\n ― Josh Billings
“Each day of our lives we make deposits in the memory banks of our children.”\n\n ― Charles R. Swindoll
“Don’t worry that children never listen to you; worry that they are always watching you.”\n\n ― Robert Fulghum
“Treat a child as though he already is the person he’s capable of becoming.”\n\n ― Haim Ginott
“If you want your children to improve, let them overhear the nice things you say about them to others.”\n\n ― Haim Ginott
“A child’s mind is not a container to be filled but rather a fire to be kindled.”\n\n ― Dorothea Brande
Hello blank fragment

Welcome to 
 PARENTING CHALLENGE. 
 
 Parenting questions designed to make the parent in you think, introspect and learn. Answer these tricky questions, enrich your parenting knowledge and sharpen your parenting skills. GOOD LUCK AND HAPPY PARENTING!

Children may lie for a reason or rarely for fun. When they lie for a reason it\'s either for achieving some sort of advantage, but mostly is done to avoid harsh consequences. The latter can be something the child fears, such as physical punishment or loss of privileges. For example, imagine that your child is handling a precious crockery (maybe helping you with some housework you were doing). But accidentally it falls down and breaks. Now if the parent\'s response is too harsh, the next time a similar accident happens, the child will make sure that you will never find out. Maybe he will lie. This will make him understand that with a lie he will be safe, but if you tell the truth the consequences can be devastating. Remember, it may be difficult to fix a broken crockery. But it\'s definitely harder to repair a shattered young mind. Very young children, especially before 3 years of age, may find it psychologically difficult to formulate and tell a lie, the reason behind which will be discussed later.

Children need your attention and time most, not costly gifts
Teach children patience. Let them know that good things come in life only if they wait for it.
Be a friend with whom your child can share anything . Listen to them like their best friend.
Don’t do everything for your children out of love. It will make them Lazy.
Let children see sufferings around them and encourage them to help others in distress.
Encourage charity. Make them know the ‘joy of haring’ from a small age.
Character is what remains in your child even if he or she has lost everything you gave in life!
Rather than telling a child what not to do, teach and show them what they should do.
Be a good listener to your child and make use of good eye contact.
Rewards work better than punishment for your child.
Love your child unconditionally, no matter how angry at them you may be.
Praise your child at least three times as much as you criticize them
Never compare your child with others, especially with siblings
Criticize your child\'s behavior, not your child.
Let your child make mistakes, face failures and learn from them
Give age appropriate responsibilities for children and praise them for their effort
The more you appreciate your child, the more confident he or she would be.
Let them know that you will always love them no matter what.
